title: darren lewis diane abbotts canned
story: NewsopinionDarren Lewis: Diane Abbotts canned mojito drama is the least of our problemsWeve got Christians being targeted around the world and kne crime going out of hand - lets not worry too much about -year-old pensioners sipping a cold drinkShareCommentsByDarren Lewis:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsopinionTheres been a storm over Dianes can "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRight now the UK is knee deep in kne crime, austerity and an NHS crisis. Mirror readers are concerned about schools, the homeless, feeding their families, climate change, religious extremism and trying to ensure their kids do not grow up worse off than they are. I suspect they really couldn’t care less about Diane Abbott enjoying a canned mojito on a train last week. Yes, she’s the Shadow Home Secretary, and yes, Transport for London have had an alcohol ban in place since then-London Mayor Boris Johnson announced it in . Abbott broke the law. Yet that law was brought in to address anti-social behavior on public transport. Not -year-old pensioners scrolling through their phones minding their own business. So while Susan Hall, who sits on the London Assembly’s Police and Crime Committee, stamped her feet in indignation along with Tory MPs Paul Scully and Bob Blackman, ordinary Londoners were just not that bothered.  In fact, Diane’s succinctly-worded tweet on Friday night both pre-empted the controversy and acted as a verbal eye-roll. “A photo of me drinking from a can of MS mojito on the Overground has been circulated,” she wrote. “I’m sincerely sorry for drinking on TFL.” Cue the hashtags #istandwithdiane and #jesuisdiane as ordinary people made their feelings clear. “I spent the day defending her even though I’m not a fan” wrote one tweeter. Hundreds either posted cans they’d bought in solidarity or selfies they’d taken on public transport holding them in support.  When Christians are among the many faiths being targeted around the world and this country remains paralysed by Brexit, the last thing on peoples’ minds – left or right – is a politician in need of a cold one on a hot day. Clearly Abbott’s critics haven’t been on a night bus, a late-night weekend tube or the summer District Line from Wimbledon after the tennis when el vino tends to flow. The real issue is the enforceability of that  law, described back then by Transport Union general secretary Bob Crow as “a half-baked gimmick designed as a publicity stunt without a moment’s thought for the people told to implement it.” Let’s hear what Abbott’s critics intend to do about addressing that. In the meantime everyone  is busy getting their priorities right.

Delaney Barnes and Solonge Green have been arrested after a teacher at their school allegedly found an eight-page murder plot titled Project  . Police say the document - marked private info and do not open - details how the teenagers intended to obtain guns, kill their nine named victims and bury their bodies. The plans further speak about the transportation of the victimsapos bodies to other locations and their disposal, specically burning and burying their bodies, the arrest report in Avon Park, Florida, states. The plans were written in great detail as to how they would lure the victims, kill the victims, and dispose of the victims’ bodies. When teachers at Avon Park Middle School found the folder last Wednesday, the girls reportedly acted hysterical.  They now remain in juvenile custody, charged with conspiring to commit homicide and commit kidnapping. Scott Dressel, Highlands County Sherf’s Office spokesman, said: It doesn’t matterthey thought it was a joke. It’s not a joke. There’s no joking about something like this. You don’t make a joke about killing people. It’s not a joke. The school has shared a statement on Facebook in an effort to prevent any incorrect information from circulating. It reads: At the end of the day yesterday two students were taken into custody at Avon Park Middle School after a teacher alerted law enforcement of a possible plan to harm others off campus. All families involved have been notied. As this is an ongoing investigation no further details will be released at this time. The probe continues.

title: touching moment dog stands leans
story: NewsDog stands and leans on owners coffin to say goodbye one last timeWilliam Schiller, known as Bill, died on April  and his dog Chief was able to bid him farewellShareCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsThe moment was captured in a photo by the -year-old granddaughter of Bills girlfriend, Anne Marie Sibthrop "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dog was able to say goodbye to his owner one last time - standing on his hind legs and leaning on the casket at a private viewing. William Schiller, known as Bill, died on April  and his beloved dog Chief bid him farewell at his private viewing in North Carolina on April . The touching photo was snapped by -year-old Nina Holcombe, whose grandmother was Billaposs girlfriend.She posted the photo on her Instagram with a caption that read, aposI miss you Mr. Bill [heart emoji].aposSam James, director at James Funeral Home in Huntersville, said: To see a dog standing on his tippy toes looking into a casket struck the heartstrings of this community.    Anne Marie Sibthrop, who was Billaposs girlfriend, said: I didn’t even know she was taking it.Anne Marie described the moment Chief said goodbye to Bill in an interview with NBC . She said: I’ll never forget. He stretched his neck in as far as he could, and he gave Bill just one little quick lick on his ear, and of course, Bill didn’t move. And Chief laid his head right down by his head, and just laid there for the longest time. Anne Marie rescued Chief in , and it was Bill who convinced her to keep him, despite his size and energy level. Bill had only once had a pet of his own, Anne Marie said.    He was in the military. He worked a full-time job. He went to school. He taught flying. He just never really had an opportunity to have a pet, she said.  I kept telling him [Bill] I’m going to have to find this dog a home, with a mommy and a daddy and kids.  He walked in the house and took one look at Chief, he didn’t say anything to me, he just took one look at this dog and said, We’re keeping that dog.apos The two had a long distance relationship until autumn , when Bill was diagnosed with dementia and moved in with Anne Marie and Chief in Huntersville, North Carolina. Bill had been living in Florida up until that time, and when he came to live with them, Anne Marie had Chief trained as a therapy dog so he could accompany them everywhere, evenBill needed care outside of their home.  James said he is often asked to accommodate a last goodbye for animals grieving the loss of their human companions. grieve when they lose somebody that they love, and I believe it helps them connect the dots in the same way it helps us connect the dots, he said.    Anne Marie was thankful the funeral home honored that wish for Chief and Bill.  He got to say goodbye to his daddy. And that was important, Anne Marie said. It meant a lot to Chief to be able to do that. He knows now that daddy’s okay, and he’s stuck with me. Bill was born in Canton, Ohio, on September , , to the late Gustave and Alma Schiller.  Bill was laid to rest in Canton on April  at Forest Hill Cemetery.

But then he stumbled across a meal plan featuring over  specic meals, recipes for said meals and lists of their favourite foods as well as ingredients to avoid. title: smoked seal sausages go sale
story: NewsSmoked seal sausages go on sale in Russia prompting outcry from animal loversAuthorities in eastern Russia have defended the sale of the controversial meat by saying it is healthy and low in caloriesShareCommentsByNeil Murphy:,  APR NewsThe meat has gone on sale in Russias far east "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSmoked seal meat has gone on sale in eastern Russia, prompting an outcry from animal lovers who have demanded that its sale be outlawed. The sausages are made by a private company in the Magadan region of Russia, some , miles from Moscow. It has been reported that about  seals have been shot or clubbed to death to make the controversial product. The flesh of the animal is being used to produce seal paté and a aposSpam-like chopped meatapos. “Seal meat not only tastes good, it is healthy — it is low-calorie and is high in nutritional value,” authorities in Magadan said.    Vasily Borisov, an entrepreneur behind the private venture, has defended its production and said his company produced , cans of spotted seal meat last year. But the resulting outcry has resulted in a petition to the Russian President Vladimir Putin to block its sale which has been branded primitive and amoral. “There is absolutely no need to kill seals, which are highly developed mammals, for food,” said Olga Salnikova, founder of the Change.org petition.    Over , people have put their name to the appeal and have insisted that seals are not sausages. Ilya Volodin, a zoologist, said: “It’s senseless to make sausage from seals because it’s cheaper and easier to make it from cows.

title: womans face left covered blisters
story: NewsWomans face left covered in blisters after botched plastic surgeryWARNING GRAPHIC IMAGES The patients skin was burnt from the inside out after she had a face tightening procedureShareCommentsByJohn Feng:,  APR NewsThis womans face broke out in horrying blisters following a botched facelt "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman suffered second-degree burns and huge blisters on the face and neck after a botched facelt. The horric experience happened at an unnamed plastic surgery clinic in Taipei, the capital of Taiwan. The woman in her s is said to have been unaware as her skin was burnt from the inside out during the much sought-after a ‘Thermage’ treatment. The face-tightening procedur relies on heating deep layers of the patient’s skin to stimulate collagen, according to the Calornia-based company Thermage.    However, after an hour of the treatment, the patient was sent home and reportedly began experiencing sharp pain on her face, followed by burn blisters. She took herself to hospital and was shocked to learn she had suffered second-degree burns during the treatment. She was put in intensive care for three weeks as a result.    Doctor Lin Shang-li, who runs the Shang-Li Dermatologic and Aesthetic Clinic in Taiwan’s northern New Taipei City, said the patient came to him for help after her traumatic ordeal. Lin said of the woman’s experience: “More often than not, it’s caused by the strength of the treatment.  “If the patient was under general anaesthesia during the procedure, she wouldn’t have been able to give the surgeons feedback in real time, she continued. “She wouldn’t have been able to tell them whether it hurt or not, leading to over-treatment and eventually burn injuries.”  Lin said he would be treating the woman’s face, which is covered in dark scars from her burn wounds. However, due to her burn injuries, she will need to wait at least two to three months before undergoing any new procedures.

title: jim mcintyre admits dundee now need miracle to stay in premiership
story: Boss Jim McIntyre has admitted Dundee now need a miracle to keep them in the Premiership.Defeat and a dismal display at St Johnstone on Saturday leaves the Dark Blues six points adrt at the bottom of the top flight with just four games remaining.And Jim reckons his team now need victories in all of those outings to have any chance of avoiding automatic demotion.Having only won that number in the league all season, and after eight consecutive defeats, to say that looks unlikely is a huge understatement.The manager and a decent travelling support were bitterly disappointed by a  minutes at McDiarmid Park when Dundee were never at the races.He did not blame fans for venting their frustration late in the - reversal.“We’re not stupid, we know we probably need to win four on the bounce to still have a chance. That’s the reality of it and we are going to have to do that,” said Jim.“We’ll keep trying, we will keep digging. We’ve let ,, or whatever it was, punters down who were giving us good backing.“Obviously, when the first goal goes in they vent their fury and they’ve got every right because it has not been good enough.“I fully understand where they’re coming from and we take it squarely on the chin.”Jim conceded yet again it was a case of players not doing their jobs as Saints cantered to an easy win thanks to second-half efforts from Scott Tanser and Callum Hendry.“Once the first goal goes in, obviously it was dficult. Again we were on the ball in the middle of the park and give it away. Then we give away the free-kick.The second goal comes from a throw-in which is again not matching a runner. It’s a simple throw-in back to the wide player and it’s a simple cross and it’s not good enough.“That’s not doing your jobs and it’s jobs that we work on, jobs that they know exactly what’s expected of them in those key areas and that’s why we’ve been punished.“It’s a major disappointment. We were so guilty of giving the ball away in key areas.“I felt we showed a lack of quality on the ball and St Johnstone fed off it, the amount of times they picked the ball up from a slack pass from us and broke.”

title: aberdeen pupils launch petition over change to study leave
story: Pupils at an Aberdeen school have launched a petition against their teachers after study leave was shortened.Harlaw Academy youngsters will have to juggle exams and classes next month and claim this will cause them to “not reach their full potential”.Study leave started last week and runs until May  – although the examination timetable does not finish until late May.It is understood other schools in the city allow their pupils to stay off for the duration of exams.Aberdeen City Council said the dates for Harlaw’s leave have been in the calendar since August last year and were developed with input from staff, parents and pupils.Staff at the school believe starting the new timetable in the middle of exams will maximise teaching time for those sitting exams at Easter next year.The petition at change.org has so far been signed by more than  people.It says: “Harlaw staff have decided to end study leave before exams finish. Many students will be missing the first week of their new classes and will be unable to properly study for their remaining exams.“As a student body we believe that our study leave shouldto its original duration.“Many pupils have exams that start during the new timetable and believe the new classes will just become a distraction and will cause students to not reach their full potential.”An Aberdeen City Council spokesman said: “The provision of study leave is a matter for inidual schools. Harlaw Academy pupils’ study leave runs from Wednesday April  until Monday May  and this has been in the school calendar since August.#The calendar was developed in discussion with staff, parents and pupils.“Harlaw Academy and Aberdeen City Council value all views and always take them into consideration.”Councillor Martin Greig, who represents the area, said: “I’m not surprised the students are unhappy with these arrangements.“It’s unfair to discriminate against a certain group who will not be able to take advantage of the study leave period.“Hopefully the council will listen to the concerns.”Ward councillor Jenner Stewart said she could see both sides.She said: “I’d like to know more detail and have a discussion with the school and the pupils to see what they’re saying.”

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a £, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: celebrate holy week ayrs oldest
story: NewsCelebrate Holy Week at Ayrs oldest churchThought to be the oldest church in the town, St Quivox Parish, Auchincruive, is rich in heritage and history.ShareByAbi Smillie:,  APR NewsSt Quivox Parish Church, Auchincruive, Ayr."Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHoly Week is celebrated by millions across the globe each year. And what better way to celebrate the religious holiday this year by visiting Ayr’s oldest church. Thought to be the oldest church in the town, St Quivox Parish, Auchincruive, is rich in heritage and history. Visible from the A, the ‘country church’ was originally a rural Parish church dating back to the late th   early th centuries. It has been a living, working church without interruption ever since. The Church of Scotland branch has seen many changes over the years. In , the church on the Auchincruive site was originally called Sanchar-in-Kyle and was described as a rectory. In , it was mentioned in connection with the founding of the Gilbertine Priory of St Mary at Dalmulin within the Parish and in  came under the ownership of Paisley Abbey when the monks left Dalmulin. At this time it was a Roman Catholic Church and after the Reformation in , and the movement away from Rome, the church became used for the Protestant form of worship.  In , a major restoration was carried out to the original long church with the addition of a T-shaped wing. A relic wooden ladle used for the collection and communion cups, said to have been presented in , are still in use today. The last structural change to the church was seen in the early th century when the Whitletts and Craigie Galleries were added above each end of the original long church. The outside gallery stairs, still in existence, speak of an older time when the landed gentry did not mix with the people seated in the body of the kirk. And it’s hard to believe that back in those days there was very much a ide among the congregation between rich and poor. But that’s certainly not the case now. Church member and Convener for Fundraising and Events, Margaret McConnell said: “It’s always been quite a poor church. “The members and residents were either miners or worked on the fields. “Of course, there were quite a lot of farmers in the area but they were the wealthy ones.”  Speaking of the upper central gallery, Interim Moderator Rev Ken Yorke said: “That’s where the lords and ladies sat. “There was a fireplace up there and the story goes that when the local gentry was sitting there,he didn’t like what the minister was saying, he’d get up from his seat and go over to the fire and sit and warm himself.” Session Clerk David McMahon joked: “We don’t have any original members left anymore.” Margaret has a long standing relationship with the St Quivox, Auchincruive. She originally went to the church as a young girl then lived overseas for several years. But she admits finding her aunt Elizabeth’s grave in the church’s graveyard brought her “back to her roots”. She said: “Faith is a journey. “I joined the church  years ago. “My family were local residents and granny came to the church every Sunday.  “They were from Whitletts and used to walk along the Low Road, but now that’s the bypass.” Her family sat in one of the galleries, to the left of the minister. She later married in the church in . And it seems ministry runs in the family for Rev Ken too, whose father was a minister at Prestwick South for  years. Rev Ken said: “It’s not all about the minister though– we have faithful people who help out. It’s a team effort. “People nowadays, their attention span doesn’t last for too long so I try to speak for a short time but get all the important parts across. “There comes a time more than ever where Christian people and communities need to come together– still do their own thing– but come together to further God’s work.” David added: “A lot of our work is trying to involve the community. “It’s about getting in touch with the people.” St Quivox Auchincruive will host Holy Week and looks forward to welcoming those who wish to celebrate the holiday.  Margaret said: “Hosting the Holy Week Services at Ayr, St Quivox Parish Church, Auchincruive provides a great opportunity for us to let everyone in the community know that the beautul old church is still open to all and welcomes everyone. “We would also like to extol the historical importance and the heritage of Ayr, St Quivox Parish Church, as two of its former ministers were Moderators of the General Assembly – one of whom, Rev Archibald H Charteris, began ‘Le and Work’ magazine and also founded the Women’s Guild.” And although very proud of their beautul and historically rich place of worship, the trio agreed “the church is the people – not the building”. story: NewsIconic Greek statute that is the double of former Celtic star John Hartson airport is left to rot at Prestwick AirportCall for action toShareByStephen Houston:,  APR NewsCorrosion on statue of Icarus at entrance to the Prestwick International Aerospace Park."Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe eight-foot high statue of Greek legend Icarus may be rotting. It is feared either below par casting or a low quality bronze may be causing problems for Icarus. For the past  years the bronze sculpture has adorned the entrance to the Scottish International Aerospace Park at Prestwick. Thousands of drivers pass him every day - and some think he’s a double for former Celtic striker John Hartson. It was commissioned by the now defunct Enterprise Ayrshire and created by the firm where Kelpies sculptor Andy Scott was lead designer. An expert who brought his fears for the sculpture to the Ayrshire Post said: “This should not be happening and my eye can also see cracks that have obviously had some filler work done. “This should not be happening. Good bronze should last without issues for generations. I just wonderon a cost basis the foundry used low quality bronze.” Untrained eyes can see rust developing on the back of Icarus’s wings and on the globe he stands on. Between his feet the surface seems dimpled and stained. One theory is it could be bronze disease, similar to what rust is on iron-based material. The matrix of copper and tin that forms bronze is attacked by hydrochloric acid which can combine with chloride in sea water. On most days Icarus is hit by salty moist air from the sea just half a mile away. In Greek mythology Icarus flew too close to the sun and his wax wings melted. He fell into the sea and drowned. An academic at Brown University at Rhode Island said: “If left untreated, bronze disease will continue to eat away at the metal to the point of complete destruction of the artact.” A study into the condition of Icarus is now to take place. A spokeswoman for Scottish Enterprise said: “The statue at Prestwick Airport was commissioned some  years ago by the local enterprise company, Enterprise Ayrshire. “We have instructed an inspection of the statue and remedial work will be undertakenrequired.” Icarus sculptor Andy Scott now lives in the US and was keen to look at images of him. He said: “Icarus was sculpted by my former company Scott Associates Sculpture  Design and I was lead sculptor. “It was cast in bronze by Beltane Studios in Peebles. It was based, I remember, on a design drawn by a local school pupil. I’ve not personally seen the sculpture for some time. Last time I did it looked just fine. Bronze does not rust. It patinates with time, and the color does alter in the environment.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnJohn HartsonPrestwick AirportUniversities and CollegesEducationAyr

story: NewsFrom Type  to a perfect A student has managed to reverse her type  diabetes after shedding a third of her body weight.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsKaty McMillan, , from Troon, reversed type- diabetes"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailKaty McMillan, , has gone from injecting insulin four times a day to not at all after slimming down to just st lb. The trainee paramedic was a size  and had a body mass indexof . when she was diagnosed with the disease at . At just ft tall and weighing st lbs, she was horried with the way she looked. Katy, from Troon, recalled: “When I look back, it feels like the big me with type  diabetes is a dferent person. “I was so self-conscious, and embarrassed to have type  diabetes so young and to have to inject in front of people.” Katy first attended a slimming group at , but struggled to lose any weight with it. And when doctors discovered her diabetes as she prepared for surgery to correct an underdeveloped jaw, she lost her confidence even more. She explained: “I was all geared up for the surgery. I’d been so self-conscious about both my weight and my jaw. I just wanted to get it sorted. “But, as the doctors were prepping me, they realised my blood sugar levels were sky high. The surgery was postponed as they ran tests, which showed I had type  diabetes. “Looking back, I’d had signs, like constant thirst, tiredness, and needing to go to urinate all the time, but I’d been too scared to go and have it all confirmed. “The diagnosis itself was devastating. I remember being shown how to inject myself, trying to do it and just sobbing, saying I couldn’t. “I then had to deal with going back to school and adjusting to this new le. I didn’t want anyone to see me injecting, and felt so embarrassed. “At that age, you just want to be like everyone . It was hell.” She went on: “I would eat rubbish – big plates of chips for lunch, then take-aways in the evening. “I did very little exercise too. I’d not long passed my driving test, so drove absolutely everywhere – including to the McDonald’s drive-thru most evenings.” Things changed for Katy when, in April , a Facebook post about WW – the new Weight Watchers – caught her eye. After initially trying out the plan, she was shocked to discover she had reduced her blood sugar levels to match those of someone without type  diabetes. She continued: “I saw these amazing before and after pictures and thought, ‘That’s what I want.’ “I knewI didn’t do it then I never would, so I contacted my WW leader Morag and went down to a meeting. “They explained how to use their SmartPoints system, which tracks food and drink to nudge users towards a more nutritious diet. “It made complete sense to me and I especially loved the app, enabling you to scan food in the supermarket and find out how many points it’s worth. “I’d tried other regimes in the past and hadn’t stuck to them, as they were so impractical. You can’t exactly go out to a restaurant and eat weight loss shakes or supplements. “But I liked WW as it didn’t bring attention to the fact I was trying to slim down. I could still eat the foods I liked, but it taught me about moderation and to stop pushing myself to eat when I was full.” Katy eventually hit her current weight of st lb and has never been happier. She no longer needs to inject insulin, she just takes two Metformin tablets a day – a drug often used to treat type  diabetes. The charity Diabetes UK says that though there is no guarantee that the condition has gone forever – it is possible to go into remission – and losing around kgincreases the chances of doing so. Katy now lives on fresh, home-cooked meals, prepared from scratch and hits the gym three times a week, where she does cardio and lts weights. She said: “My advice to anyone  out there feeling how I once did is just to take those first steps, go to that first meeting. “It doesn’t take long for change to happen. You can still go out, have fun and socialise too. “You don’t need to stop your le in order to feel dferent.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr NewsAyrBMIFacebookSupermarketsEducationSocial mediaTroon

story: NewsYoungsters put toes in the water during historic rowing event on River AyrA little history was made on the River Ayr as a ‘Come and Try Rowing’ event attracted pupils and apprentices from around South Ayrshire.ShareByPaul Behan:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsPictured are the group during their rowing taster session on the River Ayr "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAround  young adults from Prestwick Academy, Kyle Academy, Belmont Academy, Marr College, GE Caledonian and UWS Ayr, took to the water and had a splashing great time. The event involved a successful partnership between South Ayrshire Council, Scottish Rowing, University of West of Scotland and Ayrshire coastal rowing clubs. And it’s believed to be the first time in  years that an organised water-based activity has taken place on the River Ayr. The event was designed to encourage young people to interact safely with the river and get fit and active at the same time. Many of the participants will be undertaking Duke of Edinburgh Gold Awards in the summer and this event was the perfect warm-up. All the young adults were given a safety briefing by representatives from Scottish Rowing, the council and South Ayrshire coastal rowing clubs. They were then allocated their equipment before the group all had the opportunity to try out a single scull, open canoe and a costal boat, setting off along an m course. During the day they all received expert tuition from experienced rowers and instructors. Belmont Academy pupil Alex Crooks, aged , said: “It was something new, a new experience. “I’m doing canoeing for my Duke of Edinburgh award, so it’s about getting experience of the water and the river. I enjoyed it.” Ben Gilmour, aged , a pupil at Prestwick Academy, said: “It was good. “We get out and do free things and it’s good way to spend your time, instead of playing the X-Box! “I do sailing and I do figure skating but I’ve never come out and done loads of watersports . “This has been good and you get to meet new people as well.” It’s hoped that the programme will spark renewed interest in rowing and watersports, given the River Ayr’s proximity to Ayr Academy. Backing the event was the RNLI , who through their Respect the Water campaign, were able to reinforce the key messages about staying safe. The participants were also given a waterproof mobile phone cover, along with literature about water safety, as a thank-you for taking part. Tess Crooks who goes to Belmont Academy said: “It was a fun and enjoyable day, I would like to do more and get to learn new skills on the water.” Ryan Matthews, an apprentice from GE Caledonian, said: “It was a very enjoyable experience and good training for my DofE Gold canoeing expedition later in the summer. “It also made me realise the fitness required for this type of activity and how I need to get fitter.” Councillor William Grant, Children and Young People Portfolio Holder for South Ayrshire Council, said: “South Ayrshire has outstanding natural resources available to everyone. “This is a great way for young people to explore nature, increase their confidence and learn new skills at the same time. “We need to respect all our waterways but rivers should also be enjoyed and the young people taking part clearly had a great time thanks to the expert supervision.” Vincent McWhirter, RNLI Volunteer Community Safety Officer said: “We have  miles of coast line from Barassie to Ballantrae with four main rivers and numerous lochs all of which are very attractive but can also be potentially dangerous, so it was really worthwhile to teach the young people new skills and at the same time learn about the hazards but in a fun way.” If you are interested in taking up rowing, you can contact Scottish Rowing https:www.scottish-rowing.org.uk , Ayrshire Coastal Rowing Clubs: Troon Coastal Rowing https:en-gb.facebook pg TroonCoastalRowingClub posts , Prestwick Coastal Rowing https:www.prestwicksailingclub prestwick-coastal-rowing-club , Carrick Coastal Rowing www.carrickcoastalrowing.org, Girvan Coastal Rowing girvan.rowing@btinternetLike us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr

title: winding-back-time-to-when-selkirk-clock-didnt-stop
story: Following recent renovation work on Selkirks iconic town clock, it has been beset by problems.As well as regularly stopping, the four-faced clock has also been seen going backwards.Up until  the clock mechanism and chimes had been maintained and monitored by the Brown family.And for over a century it never stopped.John Brown began maintenance and the daily winding-up of the clock in .The watchmaker and jeweller, who worked out of the family business at the premises on the corner of Tower Street now occupied by the Red Cross, passed the baton to his son Tom.And likewise the maintenance and winding-up duties were passed to his son Jack.The Brown familys century-long involvement came to an end in  when Jack retired.His daughter, Margaret Smith, recalls: "The clock was wound up every Monday morning at am."I often went up the tower with my dad - you had to time your jump to avoid the pendulum on your way to the mechanism."It had to be wound up four times on each visit, once for each clock face."Although the mechanism rarely ever showed any signs of faltering, Margarets father, like his father and grandfather, would position himself next to the mechanism every Hogmanay and Common Riding to provide manual back-up in case the chimes didnt sound.Margaret added: "With all the problems we have just now with the clock people stop me to askI know whats going on."Its a dferent mechanism from the one my father, grandfather and great-grandfather looked after, so Im not sure what the problem is."

title: light-at-the-end-of-the-tunnel-on-borders-railway-claims-boss
story: SCOTRAILS boss believes the end is in sight to the turmoil on the Borders Railway.Speaking at a public meeting in Galashiels yesterday, Alex Hynes admitted the service has not been good enough.Over the last few months commuters have faced a number of cancellations on the Tweedbank to Edinburgh line due to staff shortages, as drivers are trained to operate new high speed trains.But Mr Hynes said passengers will soon see more carriages and more reliability, as the training courses come to an end.He told the meeting of the Borders Railway Community Partnership: "The service we have delivered to our customers has fallen well below the level they expect and we take full responsibility for that."There are a number of reasons for that, which have been well publicised, but we are focused on working flat out to resolve this train backlog we have had."Every single day we are having to make dficult decisions to cancel trains."We are training our Edinburgh drivers on the new high speed trains and that will be completed by the end of May."From my perspective, my priorities are threefold."Number one is we have to improve the service on the Borders Railway. Now. That is an urgent task. It is the top of my priorities."Secondly, we need to deliver more carriages. That starts next month. We will see more capacity on the Borders Railway as our new rolling stock fleets arrive here in Scotland."Thirdly, we need to work with the Scottish Government to see what we can do next to deliver a bigger and better railway for the Borders."Mr Hynes also told the meeting that the demand for the Borders Railway is increasing.He said: "In year one we saw five per cent passenger growth between years two and three that grew to  per cent. Even despite the challenges we have faced in recent months, the demand for the Borders Railway is absolutely huge."Once we get all of our high speed trains into service, that will enable us to provide more trains in the peak periods."When we opened the railway there were about  seats going up to Edinburgh in each peak period."Today, thats , seats in and out of Edinburgh and that will grow to , seats once we have all the trains into service."By putting more class , three carriage trains on the line that will enable us to provide more comfort, more reliability and more capacity for this bit of the railway network which is so badly needed."

registration, for requesting or changing postal or proxy votes and when postal votes will be issued as this could impact on those who will be away prior to and over election day on  May.ldquoFor those who do receive a postal vote, Irsquod ask that these are ed as soon as practical.ldquoNot only does this ensure that your vote counts, it also helps speed up the count process as all verication can be completed in advance.The deadline for voter registration is midnight on May  and the deadline for postal vote applications is pm on May .Anyone wishing to appoint a proxy to cast a vote on their behalf has until pm on May  to arrange this and voters hoping to change an existing postal or proxy vote have until pm on May .Borderers are eligible to vote in the European Parliamentary Election provided they are  or over on election day and are a British, Irish or qualying Commonwealth citizen permanently living in the UK, or a citizen of the Republic of Ireland or certain Commonwealth countries and are resident in the UK.Citizens of the European Unionwho wish to vote in this election in Scotland need to complete a separate application to vote, accompanied by a declaration stating that they will vote only in the UK.You can register online at www.gov.uk register-to-vote or by contacting the Electoral Registration Officer on ero@scotborders.gov.uk or  .The necessary paperwork to arrange to vote by post or proxy can be downloaded from www.scotborders.gov.uk registertovote or can be obtained from the Electoral Registration Officer.

title: mini-revival-at-this-years-festival-of-motoring
story: VINTAGE vehicle enthusiasts are doing an Italian Job on this years highly-anticipated Festival of Motoring.The Borders Vintage Automobile Clublaunched this yearrsquos festival in Hawick.And part of the celebrations was a screening of the classic s film The Italian Job.Around  guests packed into Tower Mill for the launch.In honour of the th anniversary of the release of The Italian Job, the theme of this yearrsquos Festival of Motoring will be lsquoYear of the Minirsquo.Thirlestane Castle will once again welcome vintage car enthusiasts from across Scotland for the event on June .BVAC have including a Classic Mini Cooper Raffle in aid of My Namersquo Doddie Foundation, a Big Mini Cram record-breaking attempt, a special Italian Job display, and surprise celebrity guests for the event.BVAC Chairman David Pratt said: ldquoIn a year that is jam packed with big motoring milestones and anniversaries, we are delighted to announce that the central theme of this yearrsquos BVAC Classic will celebrate  years of the Mini.ldquoAnd in another birthday celebration, quite remarkably, the Italian Job film will be exactly  years old at this yearrsquos show on the June .ldquoIt is fitting therefore, that we have officially launched the event with a screening of this absolute classic which famously starred a trio of Mini Coopers.ldquoThis is also the perfect occasion to thank our partners Brewin Dolphin and Thirlestane Castle for their continuing support as well as Emtelle of Hawick and Jedburgh, who have so generously donated the Classic Mini Cooper for our charity raffle in aid of My Namersquo Doddie Foundation.ldquoThe Club are thrilled at the response from the generous Borders public and look forward to donating this lovely little car to one lucky winner as well as raising valuable funds for research into Motor Neurone Disease.ldquoWith more than  classic and vintage vehicles of all shapes and sizes making the journey to Lauder, this yearrsquos event promises to be an absolute classic."Previously described as the Best Classic Car Festival in Scotland by the Sunday Times, the event features Veteran, Vintage and Classic Cars alongside Motorcycles, Commercial, Agricultural, Military, Steam and American Classes.The BVAC Classic will be held at Thirlestane Castle in Lauder on Sunday June  from am.For further information about the event contact Fiona Drane   or by email Fiona.drane@brightlightmarketing

title: bike-friendly-new-buses-pull-into-peebles
story: A FLEET of new bike-friendly buses arrived in Peebles this week.Borders Buses have invested pound, in three brand new vehicles to service its X, Peebles to Edinburgh, route.The vehicles, E double deckers, have been custom designed and built by bus manufacturer Alexander Dennis.Each bus accommodates up to two bike bays with, following positive feedback from customers, two additional bays being added to each vehicle by the end of May.Designed with commuters, local and touring cyclists in mind the bike friendly service is aimed at minimising car journeys.Lee Young, operations manager at Borders Buses, told us: ldquoWe recognise the way we travel is changing and active travel is increasingly becoming a popular choice with people from all walks of le."As a key transport provider, we are committed to continuously tailoring our product offerings to meet those changes in travel demand.ldquoItrsquos important to highlight one bike friendly bus could potentially take up a high number of cars off the road."With congestion in our towns and cities an ongoing issue it makes sense for commuters to ditch the car in favour of bus and bike.ldquoOur new buses hit the road this week and we cannot wait for our customers, both old and new, to make full use of our bike facility.Other features on the new vehicles include free WiFi, comfortable seating and tables, wireless and USB charging points and device friendly seat backs.The launch of the new vehicles coincides with the introduction of contactless payment across the full Borders Buses network.Scottish Borders Council leader Shona Haslam believes the new bike-friendly buses are a great addition.She said: "The Scottish Borders is the leading cycling destination in Scotland, from the forests which provides a world-class mountain biking offering to the ious cycling routes which allows people to explore our fantastic area.ldquoTweeddale in particular has an excellent offering for cyclists of all ages and abilities, including the recent extension of the Tweed Valley multi-use path and opening of the e-Bike Hub in Innerleithen.ldquoThe provision of these brand new bike friendly vehicles by Borders Buses on the main service through Tweeddale will be hugely welcomed by local people and visitors and we hope will see even more people travel here to experience the Scottish Borders.Local cyclists Colin Cotter, from Peebles, and Steven Cooper, from Dalkeith, have been recruited to demonstrate how to load bikes inside the new buses.Their video can been viewed at www.youtube watch vXoQCNFsfeatureyoutu.be

title: scottish-borders-council-leader-to-stand-in-european-election
story: SCOTTISH BORDERS COUNCIL leader Shona Haslam will be a candidate in the European election next month ndashit takes place.The Tweeddale East councillor will be third choice on the ballot paper for the Conservatives.This week the party released its full list of hopefuls for the Scotland constituency.And she is among the six names to have been put forward by the Tories.Mrs Haslam told us: ldquoI am absolutely delighted to have been selected.The former charity worker is the only candidate on the partyrsquos list from the Borders.The other hopefuls include first choice Nosheena Mobarik, an incumbent member and second choice Iain McGill, a businessman from Leith.It was also announced yesterday that former Tweeddale councillor and ex-deputy leader of SBC Catriona Bhatia will be a candidate for the Liberal Democrats.Mrs Bhatia, who is the daughter of Borders peer David Steel, is also the partyrsquos third choice behind Sheila Ritchie and Fred Mackintosh.The European elections are due to take place on Thursday, May  ndashthe UK has not left the EU by then.At total of  MEPs will be elected to represent  UK regions.At the polling station, the public will be asked to vote for a party or independent inidual.The more votes a party gets, the more candidates will be elected from their list. Other parties are also currently preparing for the election.We will bring you more details when we get them.

title: new-toy-museum-location-and-thirlestane-castle-events
story: Thirlestane Castle have announced an exciting programme for the summer, including an open-air cinema, and a new location for the Toy Museum.The castlersquos historic toy collection, which features toys, games and pictures from the past, has been relocated to the former school room on the upper ground floor.Thanks to the new location, the Toy Museum now resembles the scene of an early th century nursery in a country house, and it will prove a little wonderland for visiting children.The collection showcases items loaned from the Pollock Toy Museum in London, as well as the belongings of children who once lived at the castle.The castle, which dates back to the th century, is still the family home of the Maitlands.Edward Maitland-Carew said: ldquoIrsquom delighted our fantastic collection of historic toys will be back on display and am eagerly anticipating all of the special events, particularly the new Open-Air Cinema screenings.Thirlestane Castle features some of the finest decorative plasterworks in Europe, and one of the most extensive family collections of portraits and busts in Scotland.Mr Maitland-Carew said: ldquoItrsquos always an exciting time as we approach the start of a new visitor season here at Thirlestane Castle and I am delighted to be able to share Thirlestane Castle with visitors once again.ldquoWe are looking forward to welcoming back familiar faces, not least our wonderful volunteers, the Friends of Thirlestane.Attractions available every day include the Team Room and Gt Shop. And the castle has a line-up of events throughout the summer.The open-air cinema will take place over two occasions, first with a screening of lsquoThe Italian Jobrsquo on May  as part of the lsquoBVAC Classic ndash Festival of Motoringrsquo, and then again on September  with a film that will be announced soon.July  will see a touring theatre company Illyria perform Shakespearersquos lsquoThe Tempestrsquo with the castle as back-drop, and for Halloween the castle will host a drive-in cinema featuring ldquoGhostbusters on October .More summer activities include a camping experience for children over the months of July and August, and a civil war re-enactment over the weekend of August -.During the season, Thirlestane Castle will be open every Sunday to Thursday from am to pm, starting April  and until September .For event tickets and more information, visit Thirlestane Castle website.

title: whynot-expand-your-pioneering-retail-business-into-galashiels
story: A PIONEERING retail business which has been a huge success in East Lothian has taken over an eyesore building in Galashiels.whynot  has operated in a former North Berwick supermarket for the past six years, helping over  independent crafters, artists, small businesses and community groups rent pop-up spaces.And it has generated turnover of over pound million as well support  jobs.Now the business has branched out to take over an empty store in Galas Channel Street.The former MCo store had been empty for almost two years.Jenny Potter, one of the directors of whynot , told the Border : ldquoGalashiels has a really busy town centre and a bright future."The Borders has a huge iety of fabulous artists and makers."whynot  in Galashiels will provide a base for these and also provide concessions for community groups and not-for-profit organisations to publicise what they do."We are really excited to be part of the Borders community."As well as giving crafters and small businesses a high street presence, there are wider benefits to the whynot  business model.Jenny added: "Each and every person who takes space in whynot  has the opportunity to grow their business at a pace that suits them."One of our retailers in East Lothian started out five years ago with just a small table for one day a week, gradually building up more space and staying seven days a week."Now shersquos about to leave us and move into her own retail premises, employing three staff."Since we opened we have had almost  retailers establish themselves in whynot  where theyrsquove grown their business to the point of taking on their own premises and becoming employers themselves.ldquoBut thatrsquos not what everyone is looking to do."The beauty of whynot  is that itrsquos so flexible and there are options for people to work at their own pace on a level that suits them. People can take space for only one daythey like or two or three. Some people donrsquot like the selling part of retail so we have options where we can do that on their behalf.Galashiels-based Emma Milner-Smith, who along with her husband Guy, owns The Tartan Penguin.She has been using whynot  in North Berwick and recommends similar companies to take advantage of the new opening.Emma said: "We left our full time jobs to establish our craft business two years ago."Initially we travelled around lots of fairs and shows that are held across the country but then we discovered whynot  in North Berwick."That was a real game changer for us. It gave us a soft start but a firm base to trade from. Our sales have been fantastic and we canrsquot wait to be part of the new whynot  right on our doorstep in Gala!"As well as space for makers and artists the new premises will have a separate cafe and in the near future a delicatessen, greengrocers and bakery.

title: galashiels-woman-with-multiple-sclerosis-shares-her-story
story: A Galashiels woman with multiple sclerosishas shared her story to show support for MS research in Scotland.Kirsty Bennett, , works in finance and was diagnosed with relapsing remitting MS in .Today marks the beginning of MS Awareness Week.MS Society Scotland are raising support for research that hopes to find a cure for the condition. Ms Bennett has praised the on-going studies in Scotland.She said: ldquoMS research is definitely in a good place and heading in the right direction.ldquoThe progress, in terms of new disease modying therapies and new results, definitely gives you a mental boost and some hope.ldquoMy dad had MS and there has been a huge sht since he was living with the condition and itrsquos really important that that continues. There are more treatments for relapsing remitting MS and we are closer than ever before to reaching a breakthrough for the progressive forms of the condition.MS affects brain and spinal cord as the coating that protects the nervesis damaged, which can cause a range of symptoms from tremors to fatigue.Around  per cent of people with MS are initially diagnosed with relapsing remitting MS, which causes distinct relapses of symptoms that then partially or completely fade away.Dr Anne Astier at the University of Edinburgh is positive about the progress made by medical research and the potential for further developments. She said: ldquoMS is a very complicated condition with a number of factors determining whether you might get the condition.ldquoIt is thought that one of those factors is vitamin D, which might play a role in why prevalence in Scotland is so high.Scotland registers one of the highest rates of MS in the world, with more than , people living with the condition.Dr Astier believes her research, funded by the charity, into the role of vitamin D in MS could help develop better treatments with fewer side-effects, and she is optimistic about the progress being made.She said: ldquoWersquove come a long way in the past  to  years and Irsquom optimistic, as I think many people are, that we are getting ever close to stopping MS.Research topics in Scotland range from nerve regeneration to what causes fatigue in MS.Ms Bennett added: ldquoI take a special interest in the research going on in this country and further afield ndash I find that the more I know, the better I feel ndash so Irsquod like to say thanks to the research community for their hard work and dedication.ldquoEvensome of the research being produced is not directly about my type of MS it is good to hear about the progress being made. MS Society currently funds  projects across Scotland, and  more in the rest of the UK.Morna Simpkins, director of MS Society Scotland, said: ldquoFinding more ndash and better ndash treatments for people with this often painful and exhausting condition is our priority as we continue to look for the breakthroughs that will one day produce a cure.More information about the charity can be found on the charityrsquos website.

title: shout-about-the-little-unsaid-coming-to-selkirk
story: AHEAD of their highly-anticipated new album being released alt-folk stars The Little Unsaid are set to play in Selkirk.The Glastonbury favourites are one of the most exciting emerging bands in the country.The Little Unsaid began le in a tiny West Yorkshire town when a teenaged John Elliott rescued an old PC and microphone from the trash and began making records with them.Since then with long-time collaborators Tim Heymerdinger , Alison DrsquoSouzaand Mariya Brachkovathe band has toured the UK and Europe extensively, played major UK festivals including Glastonbury, garnered a dedicated followingThe winners of the Steve Reid InNOVAtion Award for boundary-pushing new music The Little Unsaids reputation is expected to continue growing with the release next month of their new album.They spent large chunks of  and  travelling the UK and Europe, leaving audiences emotionally rapt with a live show thatrsquos been described as lsquoa thumping depth of passion, recalling the intensity and melancholic overtones of Nick Cave and Leonard Cohenrsquo.Touring continues in earnest through next month in support of first single ldquoRoad and the new album ldquoAtomise.And squeezed between dates in Inverness and Bath is a Saturday night show at The String Jam Club in Selkirk on May .ldquoAtomise was written during the summer of , Elliott shutting himself away from the outside world in a remote rural Pembrokeshire cottage where he recorded rough demos of the entire album on an old upright piano.The demos were later taken to the bandrsquos North London studio where Tim Heymerdinger played drums and Elliott added further instrumentation with recording engineer Sonny Johnsat the helm.Many of Elliottrsquos original skeletal demos were maintained in the final recording sessions as their distinct solitary mood - complete with creaking piano keys and nearby birdsong - had captured something very special.The Little Unsaid violist Alison assembled a string quartet in Stoke Newingtonrsquos th century church to lay down the string parts on ldquoAtomise and the final mix was created in Oxford by composer and orchestrator Graeme Stewart, whose credits include film music with Jonny Greenwood .The String Jam Club date on Saturday, May  will be a rare chance to see one of the countrys most inspiring and talented new bands up close.

title: mooie-brings-her-taste-of-the-country-to-peebles
story: CONTEMPORARY artwork is coming in from the country for a guest appearance in Peebles.Local artist Mooie Scott is bringing her new exhibition lsquoOutlinersquo to the Tweeddale Gallery in May.The series of paintings takes being inspired by the landscape to a whole new level.The canvases have been laid out on murky tracks, in burns and woodlands over several weeks or months, to become saturated and immersed in the terrain.As a result, the environment is printed directly onto each canvas.And the marks act as a template onto which painting, drawing and collage then evolve.Mooie began her art journey when she studied at the Cha School of Art in London.Over the years, her work has been exhibited in ious venues across Scotland.The exhibitions have included artwork made from soil, peat, tar, rubbish and vegetation.The Tweeddale Gallery will host the lsquoOutlinersquo exhibition from May ,thanks to the charity Live Borders.Phoebe Stewart, Assistant Curator, Live Borders Museum and Galleries commented: ldquoWe are thrilled to be showcasing Mooie Scottrsquos artwork.ldquoHer work focuses on the workings of nature which lends itself so well to the beautul Tweeddale Gallery.ldquoAs a charity, we want to help make lives healthier, happier and stronger, which Mooiersquos work definitely inspires.Visitors can set eyes on Mooiersquos exhibition from May  to July .Tweeddale Museum and Gallery are open Monday to Saturday.Admission to the gallery is free, but donations are welcomed.

title: thank-you-as-public-answers-galashiels-foodbank-sos
story: BIG-HEARTED Borderers have been hailed for their response to an SOS made by Galashiels Foodbank.As we revealed earlier this month, volunteers were running short of much-needed supplies.But following a Borderappeal, the foodbank, which is run three times a week, has now been restocked.The service is operated by church members in the Gala, Tweedbank and Melrose areas.And they have been overwhelmed with the publicrsquos response.Co-ordinator John Tucker said: ldquoWe have been delighted with the support we have received from the local community following the article.ldquoWe would like to thank everybody for their generosity.ldquoI have received between  and  emails from people wanting to donate and we have also had up to  people getting in touch to give money. Some contributions have been sizeable donations, which has gone a long way to help our bank balance.As we reported, the number of people visiting the foodbank has soared compared to last year.Statistics show that in January  the service helped  people. During the same month this year, that figure rose to .And in February   Borderers received parcels, while last month saw  come through the door. But Mr Tucker hopes the public will continue to help out with donations.He added: ldquoWe really want to continue to keep the foodbank stocked up.ldquoWe have received so many tins of beans and soup, so luckily we donrsquot need any more of those for the foreseeable future. But we want to keep on top of other items too.ldquoOur stock management techniques are not very scientic ndash so we just want to make sure we continue to have items and make sure the stocks do not run low.Foodbank volunteers will also be at the Galashiels Asda supermarket on Tuesday, April , between am and pm to collect donations.Mr Tucker said: ldquoWe are very grateful to Emma Tanner from Asda who has given us a slot in the store. She has managed to squeeze us in despite being very busy.ldquoWe also want to thank our wonderful local community again for their continued support.

title: comedy-central-star-set-for-gala-gig
story: ONE of the UKrsquos most in-demand comics, Carl Hutchinson, is bringing his hilarious new show to Galashiels.As seen on Comedy Centralrsquos Stand Up Central and The Chris Ramsey Show, and following a sold-out  tour, Geordie comedian, Carl Hutchinson is coming to the Volunteer Hall with his new show, lsquoI Know I Shouldnrsquot Behave Like Thishelliprsquo.Killer gags, highly entertaining stories, and his trademark twisted logic has made Carl a must-see fixture in the comedy world.He takes his unique adolescent approach to grown-up issues - from his family upbringing to tales of pulling sickies as a teacher, buying a house to having kids, this new show is easily the most brutally honest and hilariously self-deprecating outing for this Geordie comedian.Olly Robertson from promoters Live Borders told us: ldquoWersquore really looking forward to seeing Carl perform in the Borders."Hersquos a hilarious comedian, so we know it will be a fun night ndash it definitely fits with Live Bordersrsquo aim to help make communities happier ."The Volunteer Hall in Galashiels is a great venue and we are excited about the erse programme of events coming to us this Spring."Comedy fans can see lsquoI Know I Shouldnrsquot Behave Like Thishelliprsquo on Sunday, May  at the Volunteer Hall, Galashiels.The curtain goes up at pm and tickets, priced at pound, are available from Border Events on   or online in Eventbrite.

title: final-touches-ahead-of-studio-clubs-annual-show
story: ONE of the most highly-anticipated art events in Galashiels takes place next month.The Annual Exhibition of Galashiels Studio Club takes place on Saturday, May .The exhibition in Old Gala House features the talent of new and well-known Border artists, including the work of members, professional local artists, and the winners of the Young Artist Award from Galashiels Academy.Visitors can expect to see a wide range of work, from landscapes, still le, and portraits to abstract painting: all will be featured in this exciting, ied exhibition.Phoebe Stewart, Assistant Curator for charity Live Borders said: ldquoThe Annual exhibition of the Galashiels Studio Club work is always very popular with visitors."Itrsquos an excellent opportunity for professional local artists to exhibit their work in a professional gallery and a brilliant opportunity for visitors to see a huge iety of the many talented artists that reside in the Scottish Borders, helping to make communities healthier, happier and stronger.The exhibition runs from Saturday, May  to Sunday, June  at Old Gala House, Scott Crescent, Galashiels.Admission is free, although donations to the charity are welcome.The gallery is open between am and pm.

title: michaels-images-are-in-the-frame
story: A STUNNING new exhibition, The Borders and Beyond, by photographer Michael A Fitch opens in the Robson Gallery at Halliwellrsquos House Museum and Gallery in Selkirk next month.Michael, who is an international multi-award-winning photographer, will display photographs taken prior to him moving to Scotland in , as well as the captivating images he created after he discovered the beauty of the Borders.Originally from America, Michael has now retired to Selkirk where he is the owner of Hainingside Gallery.He told us: ldquoCapturing a moment in time and the feeling that goes with the image is an incredible joy."The exhibition runs from Saturday, May  to Sunday, July  at Halliwellrsquos House Museum and Gallery.Admission is free, although donations to the charity are welcome.Phoebe Stewart, assistant curator for promoters Live Borders, told us: ldquoWe canrsquot wait to see Michaelrsquos incredible work showcased at Halliwellrsquos House."His work really captures the beauty of nature in the Borders."As a charity, we value the ability to showcase this award-winning photographer and bring his work to Selkirk."Halliwellrsquos House Museum and Gallery is open between am and pm from Monday to Saturday as well as noon to pm on Sundays.

title: innerleithen-family-get-scaly-surprise
story: A local family shared the bank holiday sun with an entirely unexpected visitor this weekend.Bruce Baker, of Innerleithen, thought that his children were playing a prank when they shouted for him to come and see the snake in the familyrsquos garden.A quick glance outside, however, confirmed that there was indeed a -foot snake lurking next to his house.Mr Baker told us: ldquoThe thing was huge, I was just standing staring at it in amazement.ldquoI was shocked that the kids had been playing so close to it.ldquoI put the kids inside and came back out - It was completely still to begin with, but I nudged it with my foot and it started moving.ldquoI phoned the Scottish SPCA and they advised me to try and contain it within a box.ldquoMy neighbour helped me get it into a plastic toybox - Irsquom glad he was dealing with the head end!ldquoIt was actually very calm, Irsquom not sureit maybe had a touch of sunstroke.ldquoThe SPCA officer arrived about an hour and a half later, by that time most of the street had been over to look at our new pet!ldquoThe officer thought that it may have been on the loose for up to  weeks, due to its condition, but they werenrsquot aware of anybody in the area owning a snake like that.The snake, believed to be an escaped domestic pet, was taken to Edinburgh where it will be looked after while the charity attempts to reunite the uninvited guest with its owner.

title: 200000-community-fund-for-scottish-borders
story: ENERGY firm SSE Renewables has opened the third round of its Scottish Borders Sustainable Development Fund, making pound, available to support transformative community projects.The Fund is open to non-profit organisations, community groups and charities across the region.Successful projects will have the potential to deliver transformational social, economic and environmental changes in the local area and support long-term community development.They will also be expected to increase opportunities for education and employment, build resilience and protect vulnerable residents or stimulate meaningful community regeneration.SSE Renewables created the Sustainable Development Fund as part of its community benefit arrangements from its onshore renewable energy developments in Scottish Borders.The second round of the fund provided over pound, to six local projects to support youth development, heritage and rural economy initiatives.Successful projects included Garvald Home Farm, who were supported to improve farm facilities at a social farm and Young Enterprise Scotland, who received funding to deliver an enterprise programme in the Borders.Morven Smith, SSE Head of Community Investment said: ldquoThe third round of the Scottish Borders Sustainable Development Fund provides an exciting opportunity for local communities to realise their ambitions and build stronger local economies.The deadline for applications to be received is midday on July , .Fund guidelines and an application form can be downloaded from www.sse communities sustainablefund

title: end-of-the-road-for-selkirk-vintage-rally
story: AN ageing committee is being blamed on the decision to take Selkirk Vintage Rally off the road.Since  enthusiasts from across the UK have been driving their vintage vehicles to the town every September.And tens-of-thousands of motoring enthusiasts have parked up to savour the attractions.What began as a small enthusiasts show behind Selkirk Rugby Club grew to become one of Scotlands biggest vintage rallies after moving to Sunderland HallBut a decision was reached last week to make the  Selkirk Vintage Rally the last one as committee numbers are down to just a handful.Gordon Edgar from the Selkirk Vintage Rally committee said: "There are only three or four committee members left and we are all at the stage where we are wanting to retire."Weve been trying to recruit younger people to come onto the committee but we havent been able to"It must be remembered that Selkirk Rally is not a club, there are no club members to help with the running of the rally, it is all done with what is a very small committee and volunteers."Plans are now being put in place for the final rally, which is held on Sunday, September , to be the biggest and best.Mr Edgar added: "We have had some excellent rallies over the years and we are grateful to landowner Robert Smillie and farmer John Turnbull."We would like to thank all the exhibitors, sponsors, volunteers and the wider general public for supporting the rally over the years."Its been a great  years and we hope to make the final rally as good as any that have gone before."Entries are already coming in for the  dferent classes at the  Selkirk Vintage Rally.And there will be a special celebration to mark the centenary of the Fordson tractor.

title: galas-festive-boost-from-fundraising-fitters
story: GALAS Christmas lights have received an Easter boost from local tyre firm Ostles.The Currie Road company donated pound from every tyre sold on Good Friday to help the towns festive lights committee.And over the weekend staff members Angela Elliot and Emma Tanner handed over a cheque for pound to Leanne Ford from the Galashiels Christmas Lights appeal group.Further fundraisers are planned by the group over the coming months, including a Bake Sale at Borders General Hospital on Monday, May  and a Race Night at the MacArts centre on Friday, May .Supporter Bill Jeffrey is also attempting a coast-to-coast walk to further boost the fundraising.

title: jim-clark-rally-under-starters-orders-as-november-comeback-confirmed
story: BORDERS motorsport fans were given a huge boost with the news that the Jim Clark Memorial Rally is set toin November.The famous event willon November  and , ending a five-year hiatus.No closed-road rally events have been staged in Scotland since three spectators died at the  rally.However, a recent change in Scottish law will allow the rally toto Borders roads.The Jim Clark Memorial Rally has historically been held in May, but this yearrsquos comeback race has been pushed back with organisers keen to avoid clashes with other motorsport events.Speaking about the changes to the law which have facilitated theof rallying to Borders roads, Cabinet Secretary for Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity, Michael Matheson, said: ldquoWe have a proud tradition of Motorsport in Scotland and this government recognises the need to balance the potential for economic benefits and public enjoyment from motorsports with a high degree of safety.ldquoWe have listened to motorsports governing bodies and taken steps which will simply the consideration of events by creating a robust and proportionate framework for the authorisation of motorsport on public roads in Scotland.ldquoWe know that motorsports can be dangerous and that the risk needs to be correctly assessed and managed, however, this step will help usher theof major sporting events to our communities, boosting local economies and help to continue Scotlandrsquos rich legacy in motorsport.

title: strongest-line-up-yet-for-latest-chapter-of-borders-book-festival
story: BORDERS Book Festival director Alistair Moffat believes the  line-up is the strongest in the literary celebrations -year history.More than  exciting and eclectic events will make up the four-day festival this June.Amongst the headline names are wildle presenters Kate Humble and Michaela Strachan, Grand National legend Bob Champion, much-loved writer Alan Titchmarsh, and stars of comedy Alexei Sayle and Susan Calman.Tickets for Formula Ones David Coulthard, snooker great Stephen Hendry and the man who inspired Scottish rugbys greatest ever comeback, Gregor Townsend, will also be in high-demand.And, in this time of political unrest, it will likely be standing-room only to hear the views of Ruth Davidson, Dominic Grieve MP, Matt Chorley, Fintan OrsquoToole and James Naughtie, as well as the ever-popular satirist Rory Bremner.Alistair told us: "After a long winter and much discontent, the clouds are parting and a brilliant sun will shine on Harmony Garden in June."The marquees will rise, the seats will be set out, the sound systems installed, the show will begin and the spells of enchantment will weave their magic."For four glorious, glowing days, the world will come to Melrose to celebrate at what Michael Palin, Prue Leith and Neil Oliver have hailed as the best book festival in Britain."In  new faces will be everywhere, from lovely Alan Titchmarsh, Kate Humble, Michaela Strachan, David Coulthard and Fintan OrsquoToole."And in sessions with fascinating, unexpected storytellers, you will hear a pin drop."The epic tale of Lara Prior-Palmerrsquos victory in a thousand-kilometre Mongolian horse race will thrill and David Wilsonrsquos amazing le as a former prison governor and criminologist will leave audiences wide-eyed."The wonderful Walter Scott Prize has laureated the best of historical fiction for ten years and we plan a mighty celebration."In fact, the whole festival, with the strongest programme ever, is just that title: eyemouth-primary-rebuild-given-priority-over-earlston
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has agreed to prioritise rebuilding Eyemouth Primary School over EarlstonScottish Government funding is not forthcoming.At a meeting of the councilrsquos executive committee last Tuesday, councillors were asked to nominate Eyemouth as the preferred projectthe local authority has to provide the capital funding itself.Martin Joyce, the councilrsquos service director for assets and infrastructure, presented the report to the committee.He said: ldquoEyemouth is facing signicant capacity issues, in addition to the ious condition and suitability issues, and is currently operating at  per cent of capacity.ldquoThis is projected to rise over the next five years with a concomitant rise in the high school role which has also seen recent increases.ldquoAccordingly, it is proposed that Eyemouth Primary School is considered as the next immediate primary school investment proposal and it is recommended that a full design process and costings begin immediately to ensure this can be progressed as a priority while funding discussions continue with Scottish Government.ldquoIn the event, however, that Scottish Borders Council has to fully fund the capital cost of Eyemouth Primary School, this would have the consequential impact of delaying the construction of the replacement Earlston Primary School.However, Mr Joyce confirmed thatsufficient funding can be acquired for both schools then the two projects would be progressed ldquoin parallel, and in a similar manner to Broomlands and Langlee Primary Schools.The condition and suitability of each primary school has been ranked as lsquopoorrsquo by the council, meaning that the buildings have major defects and are not operating optimally.While both schools have poor facilities, Eyemouth Primary is at a much fuller capacity than Earlston, with Eyemouth consistently sitting at round  per cent capacity over the last ten years, compared to Earlston averaging at  per cent.Furthermore, while Earlston Primary School has had a stable number of pupils over the last few years, Eyemouthrsquos pupil roll has risen from  per cent of capacity to  per cent since .East Berwickshire councillor Carol Hamilton, who acts as the authorityrsquos executive member for children and young people, said: ldquoI think it is essential for this council to update the school estate, to provide learning spaces fit for the future, to encourage young people to embrace their learning and to encourage people into the teaching profession.ldquoWersquore looking to build schools to help our children flourish in the best environment that we can provide.ldquoThe school estate initiative shows that this council not only has education at its heart, but in the community too.ldquoBoth
